arm_group.description: ham sandwich chocolate cream orange juice
ham sandwich chocolate cream orange juice

brief_summary.textblock:
The objective of this study is to examine ghrelin, amylin, glucagon and glucagon-like
      peptide (GLP)-1 responses to a test meal in lean and obese individuals.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of a Test Meal on Satiation Hormones in Obese and Normal Weight Adolescents

detailed_description.textblock:
The primary hypothesis is that obese adolescents have a disturbed balance of hormones
      associated with appetite regulation with less suppression of ghrelin and attenuated
      stimulation of GLP-1 secretion in response to meal intake compared to lean normal weight
      controls. A second aim of the study was to test which gastrointestinal peptides are most
      associated with insulin resistance.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  caucasian youth

          -  pubertal Tanner stage x, y, or z

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  fasting plasma glucose > 7.0 mmol/L

          -  significant illness

          -  taking medications

intervention.description: whole wheat bread (68 g), butter(10 g), ham (25 g); chocolate cream (90 g); orange juice (200 mL)
whole wheat bread (68 g), butter(10 g), ham (25 g); chocolate cream (90 g); orange juice (200 mL)

facility.name: University Hospital Basel, Division of Gastroenterology and Hepatology

clinical_study.official_title: Effect of a Test Meal on Satiation Hormones in Obese and Normal Weight Adolescents

overall_official.affiliation: Division of Gastroenterology and Hepatology, University Hospital Basel

primary_outcome.description: Relation of GLP-1 release to insulin secretion in normal weight and obese adolescents
primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of gastrointestinal peptide secretion in normal weight and obese adolescents

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Dynamics of gastrointestinal peptide secretion including Tmax and Cmax
secondary_outcome.measure: Association between gastrointestinal peptides and insulin release

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Non-Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Pharmacodynamics Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science
